question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work. Simplification of numerical answers is required.}

Show that
$\displaystyle \int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta = (8+3\pi)/32$
sols:
The question asks us to confirm that

\[\displaystyle \int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta = (8+3\pi)/32\]

So we will calculate the integral on the left hand side, and then
compare our answer to the given right hand side.

The key identity is the double angle formula for cosine,

\[\displaystyle 
\cos 2x = \cos^2x-\sin^2x = 2\cos^2x-1\]

where the second equality came from
$\displaystyle \sin^2x + \cos^2x = 1$. This gives

\[\displaystyle 
\cos^2x = \frac{1}{2}(\cos 2x+1)\]

and hence

\[\displaystyle 
\cos^4x = \left(\frac{1}{2}(\cos 2x+1)\right)^2\]

Then with $\displaystyle x = \theta$,

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta & = \int_0^{\pi/4} \left(\frac{1}{2}(\cos 2\theta + 1)\right)^2 \ d\theta \\
& = \frac{1}{4}\int_0^{\pi/4} (\cos^2 2\theta + 2\cos 2\theta + 1) \ d\theta
\end{align*}

''Note that this is \textbf{not} a substitution in the integral. All we
do is rewrite \emph{cos\textsuperscript{4} $\theta$} using the double angle
formula.''

We notice that we have a term that looks like
$\displaystyle {}\cos^2\text{(something)}$ again. The identity above
holds for any argument and so we could write

\[\displaystyle 
\cos^2\clubsuit = \frac{1}{2}(\cos 2\clubsuit+1).\]

We have $\displaystyle {}\cos^2(2\theta)$ and so we can replace
$\clubsuit$ with $\displaystyle 2\theta$

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta & = \frac{1}{4}\int_0^{\pi/4} (\cos^2 2\theta + 2\cos 2\theta + 1) \ d\theta \\
& = \frac{1}{4}\int_0^{\pi/4} \left[\frac{1}{2}(\cos(2(2\theta)) + 1) + 2\cos 2\theta + 1\right] \ d\theta
\end{align*}

To make things cleaner, we'll factor out $\displaystyle 1/2$ from every
summand in the integral:

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta & = \frac{1}{4}\int_0^{\pi/4} \left[\frac{1}{2}(\cos 4\theta + 1) + 2\cos 2\theta + 1\right] \ d\theta \\
& = \frac{1}{8}\int_0^{\pi/4} [(\cos 4\theta+1) + 4\cos 2\theta + 2] \ d\theta \\
& = \frac{1}{8}\int_0^{\pi/4} [\cos 4\theta + 4\cos 2\theta + 3] \ d\theta
\end{align*}

Now, we can integrate each term, remembering the scaling factor:

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi/4} \cos^4 \theta \ d\theta & = \frac{1}{8}\int_0^{\pi/4} [\cos 4\theta + 4\cos 2\theta + 3] \ d\theta \\
& = \frac{1}{8} \left[\frac{1}{4}\sin 4\theta + 2\sin 2\theta + 3\theta\right] \big|_0^{\pi/4} \\
& = \frac{1}{8} \left[\frac{1}{4}\sin \pi + 2\sin \frac{\pi}{2} + 3\frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\sin 0 - 2\sin 0 - 3 \cdot 0\right] \\
& = \frac{1}{8} \left[2+\frac{3\pi}{4}\right] \\
& = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{3\pi}{32}\\
& = (8+3\pi)/32
\end{align*}

as required.
hints: Think about the double angle formulas.
You have to use double angles twice!
